subject: RE: [junit] execute shell command in Junit to start server?
msgSnippet: In addition to JB s comments in a later email, I add the following comment(s): You do not need to test the behavior of start.sh, just that your Java class can
messageBody:
In addition to JB's comments in a later email, I add the following
comment(s):

You do not need to test the behavior of start.sh, just that your Java
class can execute a shell script named start.sh. The responsibility of
your Java class is to execute a shell script. The responsibility of
start.sh is to execute some other commands. Only test what you need to
test.

So, you can mock up a start.sh that your Java class executes which
simply prints "ok" to standard out and then check standard out to see if
"ok" was printed there. This let's you know that you can execute a shell
script named "start.sh".

This is all assuming that you have a Java class that will actually
execute start.sh. From what I see, your test is actually executing
something (not start.sh) explicitly and not testing some other Java
class. If my assumption is incorrect, and you really want to test the
execution of a shell script using Java, then I ask, "Why Java?" Why not
use a shell script to test the execution of a shell script?

import java.util.*;
import java.io.*;

}

try{

BufferedReader inCommand = new BufferedReader(new
InputStreamReader(child.getInputStream()));

}

public static void main(String[] args)

StartServer s= new StartServer();
s.testProgramStarted();
junit.textui.TestRunner.run (StartServer());

}
}
